If two markets are pretty much guaranteed to make money over the next decade separately it's artificial intelligence and cannabis. Together, the pair could form a perfect storm thanks to COVID-19 driving demand. Cannabis is more popular than ever thanks to lockdowns and vape technology and the market is predicted to be worth $76.3 billion by 2027). A.I. adds new business benefits for the industry that the COVID boom could mean big changes ahead for regulation. Adrian Holguin, CEO of CannaShark Consulting , started consulting for cannabis companies in 2017, and in three years he says the changes have been dramatic. Previously a Silicon Valley alum working in intellectual property and patents and trademark work, Holguin, now works with entrepreneurs and startups entering the cannabis industry and is bullish on the impact that AI is having: "The use of A.I. sensors allows us to keep track of every element of the cultivation process such as water level, P.H. level, temperature, nutrient feed, etc. A.I. will also help in a lot of the automation process. Indoor growing has a history of heavy resource consumption for water and electricity, Artificial Intelligence and robotics allow the cultivating process to be more efficient and effective." Holguin, believes the future of the pairing will help not only with environmental controls and quality control but A.I. also offers more business operations benefits; "A.I. can help with cost-benefit analyses of purchasing manufacturing equipment or analyzing risks before implementing new techniques into the grow-process. If the use of A.I. in cannabis continues to go down the same path as big agriculture, it will ultimately help to reduce the costs of labor." Big issues face the cannabis industry from different fronts. Legally, cannabis continues to see roadblocks, regulation changes, and challenges from across the political divide. For example, CBD, THC, and CBN are all given different National Institute on Drug Abuse classifications even though they come from the same plant. There are more than just regulatory issues for cannabis. One of the most unmentioned surrounds banking, many institutions simply don't want cannabis companies as clients. The same comes with A.I. startups, thanks to the big guns scooping them all up (Google, Facebook etc). A brain drain is happening at a cost to fill 10,000 AI-related jobs budgeted more than $650 million for salaries. Some forecasts in Canada have been downgraded . COVID-19 may change this but banking and societal views remain big barriers for scaling businesses. Research and testing also remain an issue for the industry although this is a key area that AI can assist in. As does, state voting; Vivien Azer, Managing Director, Cannabis; Consumer – Beverages, Tobacco for Cowen believes that if New Jersey voters choose to legalize the drug, it could cause a domino effect in neighboring states like New York, Pennsylvania, and others to adopt similar standards. The biggest issue may not be these issues though. getting talent might be. Big tech companies have been actively hoovering AI startups, not just to acquire technology or clients but to secure qualified talent. The pool of true experts in the field is small, and Alibaba, Amazon, Facebook, Google, and other tech giants have hired most of the available talent. Companies have adopted M&A as a way to sign up top talent, a practice known as “acqui-hiring,” for sums that typically work out to $5 million to $10 million per person, according to a recent A.I. report by McKinsey .

urn:contentItem:5R59-3PD1-J9XT-P0B0-00000-00Big Media scrambles to meet challenge from Big Tech2017-12-11T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:21:19ZLexisNexisBig Media scrambles to meet challenge from Big Tech


DHAKA: The official news Agency of Bangladesh (BSS) has issued following news release:
America's media giants have seen this movie before: Big Tech enters an industry with piles of cash and new ways of doing business, devastating the competition.



That's why Big Media are scrambling for partnerships and tie-ups to bolster their content arsenal in the face of a well-funded onslaught from the tech sector.

This shifting landscape helps explain talks between Walt Disney Co. and 21st Century Fox to sell key television and film assets from the Rupert Murdoch family-controlled group, and a proposed AT&T purchase of media- entertainment powerhouse Time Warner.

More deals are likely as the industry adapts to a consumer shift to online, on-demand services like Netflix, and efforts by tech giants such as Facebook and Apple to jump into original content.

"It's an incredibly complicated game of musical chairs happening simultaneously," said Robert Thompson, who heads Syracuse University's Bleier Center for Television and Popular Culture.

"Everyone is trying to make sure that when the music stops they have enough content and people to keep making it for them."

- 'Game of Thrones' -

The old model of hefty pay TV packages supporting the content creators is fading, and the struggle for power in the industry is now referred to by some analysts as a "Game of Thrones," a reference to the popular HBO series.

Streaming services like Netflix and Amazon have already disrupted the sector. According to a report by the investment firm Raymond James, 31 percent of Americans said their primary source of video was streaming services.

About 32 percent of consumers have canceled or "traded down" to a less expensive package, and many young viewers rely entirely on Internet platforms for video, the report said.

Google-owned YouTube is also ramping up its original content offerings and Apple has reportedly created a $1 billion war chest for its television service programs.

"It's more than taking away money and subscriptions. It's about viewership, eyeballs," said Bruce Leichtman of Leichtman Research Group, who follows media and entertainment.

Richard Greenfield, an analyst at BTIG Research, says the established "legacy" companies are being forced to sell, diversify or "scale up" to compete against tech players.

But Greenfield said Disney's plan to acquire Fox's stake in Sky TV and studio assets while gearing up for its own streaming offerings may not be enough.

Disney, which owns the ABC television network along with ESPN sports channels, still appears wedded to "legacy distribution platforms," Greenfield said in a research note.

urn:contentItem:5XR0-SS21-DXY4-X123-00000-00Big Money To Break Up Big Tech2019-12-11T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:21:19ZLexisNexisSection BColumn 0Business/Financial DeskPg. 1Big Money To Break Up Big TechBy David McCabe

Major nonprofits and other organizations have pledged millions of dollars toward groups trying to build a modern trust-busting movement.

WASHINGTON -- Critics of big tech companies are eager to keep up their momentum -- and some of the country's wealthiest foundations are providing the financial firepower.

Major nonprofits including the Ford and Hewlett Foundations have pledged millions of dollars in total toward taking on the power of the country's corporate giants like Facebook and Amazon. Other supporters include groups run by George Soros, the billionaire financier, and Pierre Omidyar, an eBay founder.

The foundations regularly fund critical looks at capitalism. The Ford Foundation, for example, supports many organizations that study and fight inequality. The Hewlett Foundation, whose lineage goes back to a founder of Hewlett-Packard and has a $10 billion endowment, has put a slice of its money toward organizations re-examining the free market economic policies that dominate Washington.

But the financial support is reaching new heights, and it could help the activists keep pressure on Silicon Valley by building the sort of political might that has powered liberal policy victories on issues like civil rights and net neutrality. Activists recently announced a coalition to take on Amazon, for example, that includes organizers around the country.

One of the groups receiving foundation money is led by Chris Hughes, a Facebook co-founder who now publicly argues for breaking up the social media giant. His group, the Economic Security Project, is pooling some of the money and then distributing it to projects focused on antitrust and concentration concerns. Mr. Hughes, wealthy from his time at Facebook, has contributed some of the money himself.

The Economic Security Project plans to give antitrust activists $10 million over the next 18 months. On Tuesday, the organization will announce how it plans to spend the first $3 million, putting the money toward grass-roots organizers, researchers at several Washington think tanks and a group that recruits artists to make graphics that ''expose how our economy really works.''

The coming years will test whether the efforts of the advocates can harness the skepticism about large corporations and the wealthy that is animating the Democratic presidential primary race. Federal and state officials have already announced investigations into Amazon, Facebook, Google and Apple.

Ultimately, these advocates hope to address corporate concentration in numerous businesses, including drugs and farm products, and combat rising economic inequality.

They have their work cut out for them. Tech companies spend tens of millions of dollars on lobbying every year. And antitrust issues hinge on dense questions of law and economics that don't fit on bumper stickers.

''It's not just about trends and corporate accountability,'' said Maria Torres-Springer, the vice president for United States programs at the Ford Foundation, which has a $12 billion endowment. ''It's about creating and sustaining a movement that rebuilds political and economic power for everyday Americans.''

A leading beneficiary of the money is the Open Markets Institute, a research group whose focus on antitrust issues has been pivotal in making corporate concentration a matter of public debate. It expects to bring in more than $3 million in 2020, according to an internal document from the first half of this year. In 2016, before the group split off from a bigger organization, New America, its revenue topped out at just over $900,000.

This year, the Knight Foundation, which focuses on journalism, awarded Open Markets $2 million to study the impact that concentration among technology platforms has on the media. In September, the Ford Foundation gave it $200,000 to examine how tech monopolies affect workers. A public campaign it has led to break up Facebook will expand to include Google next year, according to Sarah Miller, the organization's deputy director.

Mr. Hughes's Economic Security Project is contributing to that campaign. It is also paying for Open Markets to conduct public opinion polling.

''Our view is you need an ecosystem,'' Mr. Hughes said. ''You need a community of people who generally share the same values but who, among themselves, may even have different approaches to the issues.''

Another progressive group, Jobs With Justice, plans to hold sessions next year explaining to people the antitrust case against tech companies in simple terms. In the draft script of the training, the session's leader seizes on a simple metaphor, asking attendees to consider two lemonade stands.

The first stand belongs to someone whose family owns the local grocery store, so it gets its lemons free. The family's neighbors, who opened a competing stand, aren't so lucky. Over time, the first stand is able to slash its prices to undercut the second stand.

The session leader asks for a volunteer to play the person running the stand that can't use a family connection to get free fruit. The volunteer has to decide whether to engage in a price war with the more powerful competitor while an organizer charts the volunteer's dire financial situation on butcher paper.

Each situation ends with the volunteer's lemonade stand closing and a revelation: Amazon, the session leader will tell participants, has used this tactic against its competitors.

''What we wanted to do was create some field materials, some training materials, just to even explain what a monopoly meant for people,'' said Erica Smiley, Jobs With Justice's executive director. ''Outside of people maybe playing the board game, it's kind of an old idea that maybe they learned in their fourth grade civics class but haven't necessarily re-upped on.''

Ms. Smiley's group is one participant in Athena, the new coalition organizing opposition to Amazon over antitrust, privacy and other concerns. The coalition says it wants to raise $15 million in its first three years.

Athena will receive money from Mr. Hughes's fund, along with other groups trying to rally the grass roots to the cause.

The civil rights group Color of Change plans to use its funding from the project to pay for new hires to lead public campaigns around antitrust issues, while the Action Center on Race and the Economy will run ''corporate campaigns designed to influence the public narrative on corporate concentration and win real victories for communities of color around the country.''

Other projects, like the artists' group, are focused on finding new ways to explore the antitrust issue. Mr. Hughes's group paid for a New York event in November -- held by a project called the Museum of Capitalism -- where people could play versions of the board game Monopoly that are meant to call out inequities in the economy.

Mr. Hughes will also finance some groups doing academic research on corporate concentration and intends to support more researchers in the future.

''If you're going to see real change, you need a community of scholars who are in dialogue with one another,'' he said.

Money is already flowing to campuses. In November, the Knight Foundation allocated $3.5 million to researchers to examine questions about digital platforms, including competition issues.

The foundation, along with Mr. Omidyar's philanthropic network, has also provided the money to introduce an antitrust-focused initiative at Yale's business school. In an interview, Sam Gill, a Knight executive, said the foundation had not yet taken a position on whether there should be an antimonopoly movement but felt it was important to finance inquiries into the questions posed by major tech companies.

In recent years, more potential solutions to corporate concentration have emerged. While some believe in aggressive approaches like breaking up companies, others prefer new regulations or other measures.

At a conference at the University of Utah this fall, Dan Crane, a conservative law professor, challenged a group of participants including Tim Wu, a legal scholar and New York Times contributing opinion writer who is a leading voice calling for more aggressive antitrust enforcement. Mr. Crane pushed them to be more specific about the changes they would like to see in how antitrust laws are interpreted and enforced.

Over box lunches, the group wrote a statement, later published by Mr. Wu, listing legal precedents the group hopes will be overturned and policies it hopes will be enacted.

''Those who believe in a strong revival of antitrust, and a return to its antimonopoly roots, have a duty to specify what, exactly, they mean, in concrete, legal detail,'' the statement said.

Mr. Wu said that, among other purposes, the statement could be a test for judicial nominees. It's a focus reminiscent of the playbook that helped build the conservative legal movement -- which in turn shaped the antitrust laws Mr. Wu and his compatriots criticize today.

''Over a 30-year period, they won almost every one of those battles,'' Mr. Wu said. ''They just sort of said, 'Here's what it should be,' and it happened.''

urn:contentItem:60R3-4601-DXY4-X10P-00000-00Big Oil Faded. Will Big Tech?2020-08-27T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:21:19ZLexisNexisSection Column 0National DeskON TECHBig Oil Faded. Will Big Tech?By Shira Ovide

Not that long ago, it was American oil powers -- not tech giants -- that ruled the economy and influenced world events.

This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.

Less than a decade ago, Exxon Mobil was the most valuable company in the world. On Monday, it's being kicked out of the Dow Jones industrial average after nearly a century of inclusion in the stock index.

I'm mentioning an energy company in a technology newsletter for two reasons: First, as wild as it feels to have a handful of American technology superpowers rule the economy and the stock market and influence world events, oil superpowers like Exxon were in a similar position not very long ago.

And second, while it's hard to imagine Big Tech losing relevance, most people didn't predict that demand for fossil fuels would start to wane, until it did. That's part of the sweeping changes that ushered out the era of Big Oil and started the Big Tech age. Today all of Exxon is worth less than Jeff Bezos.

Exxon's star faded because the world changed, and it didn't. The question is whether what happened to Exxon is a warning about the potential vulnerability of today's tech superpowers -- or if it's the opposite: a sign of how Big Tech is invincible in ways that Exxon wasn't.

The 2012 book ''Private Empire: ExxonMobil and American Power'' described how the company at its peak helped steer U.S. foreign policy, supported sometimes authoritarian leaders in oil-rich countries and shaped people's views on important issues like climate change to suit its interests. Its author, Steve Coll, called Exxon the world's most powerful unelected force, and I've wondered for years whether big tech companies are the new Exxon.

Apple wouldn't be the company it is today without its savvy diplomatic skills in the United States and China to advance its own business interests. Facebook is so influential that it's a tool used both against and by authoritarian governments. Google shapes how government regulators and the public think about antitrust laws. It's an imperfect comparison, but big tech companies are private empires in some of the same ways as the old Exxon.

But not long after Coll's book was published, Exxon's influence and riches started to decline. The status of the world's most valuable company shifted to Apple. Exxon and other oil giants mostly missed out on the fracking boom, and on the move away from fossil fuels. Exxon still has influence like it did in the old days, but it's not the same.

''Time has marched on and these big companies have not been nimble enough,'' Clifford Krauss, a New York Times energy correspondent, told me when I asked about the comparison between Big Oil and Big Tech.

One fundamental difference is that Big Oil's fate relies on demand for a product that the companies can't control. The tech industry doesn't seem to have this essential vulnerability.

I've said here before that many tech executives live in fear of their companies dying or becoming irrelevant. They're not thinking about Exxon but about a history of technology in which evolutionary changes have ruined seemingly invincible industry leaders. But while it's possible to imagine some of the individual tech powers losing relevance -- maybe -- it's much harder to imagine the tech industry overall growing less potent or essential.

I'll leave you with two notes of symbolism about Exxon giving way to a dominant tech industry. Exxon is being dropped from the Dow Jones index because of a technical change necessitated by Apple's stock getting too expensive. And Exxon's spot is being taken by a tech company: Salesforce.com.

Tech empires can use their power for good

Apple is changing its rules to make it harder for apps to track what we do on our phones. Google is also remaking its popular Chrome web browser with a similar goal of limiting the perpetual digital tracking that is a staple of our online lives.

I've said before that digital data surveillance is out of control, and Apple and Google might be powerful enough to single-handedly change the rules for digital privacy. Sometimes we want powerful companies to assert their authority. It should still make us nervous that they have this much authority.

Here's what is happening with Apple: Very soon, most people with iPhones will start to see pop-up messages in apps that ask permission to let the app log everything they do on other apps and websites. Apps want this information, in part, to personalize the advertisements we see and to figure out if we're responding to them.

I suspect that a lot of people are going to say heck no when they get these messages, meaning fewer companies will be able to compile digital dossiers on us. (There is a good explanation from Recode on what Apple is doing and the potential effects.)

Companies tend to find workarounds for most data privacy guidelines, and Apple's latest change won't slow down the biggest digital data hogs of all, Google and Facebook. But I think Apple is taking a good step to put more guardrails around companies that try to follow our every move online and in the real world.

It is also a reminder that in the absence of effective government policy in the United States to limit digital privacy intrusions, we have Apple and Google remaking how the digital world works without input or oversight on this important policy issue.

I'm glad that these powerful companies are flexing their muscle for what I think is a worthy mission. It also makes me queasy.

Before we go ...

Common sense tips to fight the data surveillance machine: My colleague Brian X. Chen walks through questions we should ask ourselves when we get all those pop-up requests from apps that want to track what we do. The bottom line: It takes a lot of research and work on our part to be informed consumers in the digital surveillance economy.

Blame government underinvestment in technology: Some U.S. states have been quick to pay a new $300 weekly unemployment benefit, while others expect it to take until early October to send out the funds. The difference is that some states have antiquated computer systems that can't digest the programming changes for the unemployment payouts, my colleague Ben Casselman wrote.

The weird saga of TikTok is even weirder than you thought: Mike Isaac and Andrew Ross Sorkin of The New York Times have great back-room details about the U.S. government forcing TikTok to sell at least part of the app company over concerns that it's a potential conduit for Chinese spying and propaganda. This will be ugly for awhile with everyone involved trying to maximize what they get out of this drama.

Related: TikTok's C.E.O. quit after just a few months on the job. This soap opera is not what he signed up for.

But while it’s possible to imagine some of the individual tech powers losing relevance — maybe — it’s much harder to imagine the tech industry overall growing less potent or essential.

I’ll leave you with two notes of symbolism about Exxon giving way to a dominant tech industry. Exxon is being dropped from the Dow Jones index because of a technical change necessitated by Apple’s stock getting too expensive. And Exxon’s spot is being taken by a tech company: Salesforce.com.

Tech empires can use their power for good

Apple is changing its rulesto make it harder for apps to track what we do on our phones. Google is also remaking its popular Chrome web browser with a similar goal of limiting the perpetual digital tracking that is a staple of our online lives.

I’ve said before that digital data surveillance is out of control, and Apple and Google might be powerful enough to single-handedly change the rules for digital privacy. Sometimes we want powerful companies to assert their authority. It should still make us nervous that they have this much authority.

Here’s what is happening with Apple: Very soon, most people with iPhones will start to see pop-up messages in apps that ask permission to let the app log everything they do on other apps and websites. Apps want this information, in part, to personalize the advertisements we see and to figure out if we’re responding to them.

I suspect that a lot of people are going to say heck no when they get these messages, meaning fewer companies will be able to compile digital dossiers on us. (There is a good explanation from Recode on what Apple is doing and the potential effects.)

Companies tend to find workarounds for most data privacy guidelines, and Apple’s latest change won’t slow down the biggest digital data hogs of all, Google and Facebook. But I think Apple is taking a good step to put more guardrails around companies that try to follow our every move online and in the real world.

It is also a reminder that in the absence of effective government policy in the United States to limit digital privacy intrusions, we have Apple and Google remaking how the digital world works without input or oversight on this important policy issue.

I’m glad that these powerful companies are flexing their muscle for what I think is a worthy mission. It also makes me queasy.

Before we go …

Common sense tips to fight the data surveillance machine: My colleague Brian X. Chen walks through questions we should ask ourselves when we get all those pop-up requests from apps that want to track what we do. The bottom line: It takes a lot of research and work on our part to be informed consumers in the digital surveillance economy.

Blame government underinvestment in technology: Some U.S. states have been quick to pay a new $300 weekly unemployment benefit, while others expect it to take until early October to send out the funds. The difference is that some states have antiquated computer systems that can’t digest the programming changesfor the unemployment payouts, my colleague Ben Casselman wrote.

The weird saga of TikTok is even weirder than you thought: Mike Isaac and Andrew Ross Sorkin of The New York Times have great back-room details about the U.S. government forcing TikTok to sell at least part of the app company over concerns that it’s a potential conduit for Chinese spying and propaganda. This will be ugly for awhile with everyone involved trying to maximize what they get out of this drama.Related: TikTok’s C.E.O.quit after just a few months on the job. This soap opera is not what he signed up for.

urn:contentItem:60M5-B7G1-DXMP-K0WT-00000-00Bigo Technologies to shift its Hong Kong servers to Singapore: Report2020-08-17T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:21:19ZLexisNexisBigo Technologies to shift its Hong Kong servers to Singapore: ReportSoumyarendra Barik

Bigo Technology, which owns apps such as Bigo Live and Likee, is shifting its servers from Hong Kong to Singapore in response to China's enactment of Hong Kong's National Security Law, Reuters reported. Since the law was enacted in June, multiple Big Tech firms - Facebook, WhatsApp, Google, and Twitter - have suspended their mechanisms to process data requests from law enforcement agencies in Hong Kong. TikTok, a competitor of Bigo Technology's Likee, had also announced that it will cease its operations in the territory. We have reached out to Bigo for more details. The development also comes as the US is doubling down on Chinese internet companies (more on that below).

The National Security Law defines offences very broadly and allows the police to take down internet posts and punish internet companies that do not comply with data requests. For not complying with the law, companies could be fined almost $13,000 and authorities could jail employees of the internet companies for six months. If an employee refuses to remove content as ordered, they could be jailed for a year. The police can also order deletion of posts that threaten national security. Since the new law applies across the world, companies would also have to give data of users in countries outside Hong Kong.

Bigo Live and Likee were banned in India: Bigo's announcement comes as its Bigo Live and Likee were banned in India, along with 57 other 'Chinese' apps in June over national security concerns. The company also told Reuters that it had appealed to both Singapore and Indian governments following the ban. Likee had 150 million users globally as of June, as per an earnings press release by JOYY, the Chinese internet company which owns Bigo Technology. Pakistan's telecom regulator had also banned Bigo Live in July over "obscene" and "immoral" content, while issuing a "final warning" to TikTok.

The US has banned US transactions with TikTok, and has directed Bytedance to divest its assets in the US: The United States is doubling down on Chinese internet companies such as TikTok parent Bytedance, and TenCent's WeChat. On August 14, US President Donald Trump signed an executive order directing Bytedance to divest from its American assets and its rights to any user data that TikTok gathered in the country, within 90 days. Before that, Trump had barred all US transactions with TikTok and WeChat by means of an executive order signed earlier in August. Bigo is hoping "not to be caught in the crossfire", according to Reuters.

urn:contentItem:585R-Y7K1-DYRG-W1WC-00000-00Big perks of tech firms face scrutiny from IRS;TAXES2013-04-12T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:21:19ZLexisNexisMain NewsPg. A1Big perks of tech firms face scrutiny from IRSTAXESCaleb Garling and Benny Evangelista

One of the benefits of Andrew Hager's software company is a free lunch every day. But he says word that the Internal Revenue Service might count free meals and other such perks for tech employees as taxable compensation would have ramifications far beyond his paycheck.

"All of this great food infrastructure that we have in San Francisco, a lot of it is supported by companies providing lunch," said Hager, 32. "So it's more of a benefit to the entire regional economy than me just bringing chicken and rice from home."

According to a recent report by the Wall Street Journal, the IRS is looking into whether big tech companies like Google and Facebook should count their lavish - but free - meals and other perks for employees as part of their taxable compensation.

While such extras are nothing new to the workforce at large, tech companies around the Bay Area have famously pampered employees with free meals, as well as perks like transportation, massages, fitness classes and more.

But free food, some of it fine cuisine prepared by company chefs, is perhaps the most emblematic and expected perquisite. As Facebook executive chef Josef Desimone said in a 2011 interview, "Food is an oasis, a break. More than anything, the meals create a sense of community. People eating across from each other is a sacred thing."

Luring tech talent

Competition for talent has been white hot in Silicon Valley, and employers use such perks to lure candidates. For now, these benefits dodge IRS review, being deemed "non-compensatory" and thus free from taxation. With about 260 workdays in a year - likely far more at overworked tech companies - and a meal costing, say, $10, that's a sizable chunk of saved income.

Should the IRS determine that this practice falls within purview of the federal tax code, tech employees could be in for an added line on their W-2's.

And it would seem like an issue the right legislator or regulator could feast on.

"Lavish, tax-deductible Silicon Valley lunches for employees who are often already pretty wealthy from their stock options seems like the perfect issue for an enterprising politician," Megan McArdle wrote recently on the Daily Beast. "But for some reason, neither Republicans nor Democrats have picked up on this one."

The IRS declined to comment for this story. But its regulations specify that there must be substantial reasons to keep employees on-premises and feed them tax-free. This most readily applies to jobs like first responders, security guards, ship workers or child care providers, where leaving the company premises could result in detriment to the business.

Essential staff

Tech companies could argue that their employees run important computing systems - subject to unpredictable crashes - and their staff must remain on hand. Or they could argue it's essential that employees stay on-site because of the fierce competition in today's tech sector, where lost minutes are lost money.

Yet any business could make a similar argument. For the most part, says Russell Stanaland, a San Francisco corporate tax attorney, most tech companies would have an uphill battle convincing the agency that their free meals are essential.

"I suspect the IRS would win on that," he says.

But some determinations will be judgment calls, and depending on the nature of the employment, some employees could be given untaxed meals while other, less essential staff is taxed.

Bjoern Zinnssmeister's business e-mail software company in San Francisco, isn't big enough yet to provide such perks, but he questioned why the IRS might be considering the plan.

"Another tax, are you kidding me?" Zinnssmeister said. "Is that like a waiter eating in the kitchen at night and getting taxed on that? That's what California needs at this point, being more business unfriendly."

Zinnssmeister said the free meals aren't like money because he can't choose how to spend it, on food or something else.

Not all use perk

Adam Kelly, 37, a lead programmer for a software company, said he could see both sides of the issue, but questioned how the IRS could keep track of what perks employees should be liable for.

"If they employers were giving it to employees directly, then definitely it could be taxed," Kelly said. "But you could conceivably go to work every day and not take advantage of any of those things. With a bag of chips or a soda, it's not really clear-cut to me. Do we keep track of each one that we drink? I drank seven sodas, so I owe 43 cents in taxes?"

Traditionally, those expenses are considered "de minimis" expenses, says Jeffrey Kahn, a Bay Area tax attorney; their cost is so low that accounting for them is unreasonable. Sprawling platters of sushi and ice cream sundae bars are another matter, however.

A new line item

Companies of all kinds sometimes order food for important lunchtime meetings. That expense can be written off, since it's an expense of doing business. Could a tech company like Google get clever and tell its employees to discuss only business matters at lunch, but never really enforce that requirement?

"Now you're getting into situations that are very, very gray," Kahn said. "If you're having meetings every day it's going to be a lot harder to justify that to the IRS."

Were the IRS to decide in favor of taxing the meals, and a tech company continued them as a perk, Kahn says the employee would probably find a new line item on their W2, with the value of the meals they've eaten as a piece of income to pay taxes on.

And that could surely leave a bad taste.

The IRS is deciding whether employees such as these Google workers in New York should pay taxes on the free lunch perk. Karsten Moran / New York Times

urn:contentItem:5PBK-2WD1-JD3N-53V6-00000-00Big pharma the next in taxman's sights2017-08-26T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:21:19ZLexisNexisBUSINESSPg. 25Big pharma the next in taxman's sightsBen Butler, Regulation; Exclusive

Tech giants finally get the message, but the ATO's job is not done

As the tech giants told it, when it came to their Aussie offices, there was nothing to see here.

Apparently the hundreds of employees beavering away inside the slick offices maintained by the likes of Facebook and Google had nothing at all to do with the sale of hundreds of millions of dollars worth of advertisements to Australian businesses.

But, as Australian Taxation Office staff probed the affairs of tech groups as part of a crackdown on multinational corporate tax avoidance that is now 18 months old, they discovered what was really going on was quite different.

"We found people who were supposedly approving what had been done in Australia, but all we could find was some instances where they'd corrected typos," deputy commissioner in charge of international tax Mark Konza told The Weekend Australian.

"In fact, the authorisations were automatically exercised by all the parties. "Then you've really got to question who's adding the value - the person who fixes the typos offshore or the person who has wined and dined the local clients, got them across the line, shaped their marketing message with them, got them to increase their marketing placement, all those sorts of value-add activities." Through staff interviews and demands for documents - including email strings between Australian staff and their offshore counterparts - the ATO built a picture of how multinationals -operate here that enabled it to issue a series of swingeing assessments that took in not just the current year's tax bill but activity stretching back years that had previously flown under its radar.

Tax lawyers and activists agree the crackdown has had a real impact on the behaviour of multinationals, forcing them to take seriously the ATO's demands.

Konza's boss, Tax Commissioner Chris Jordan and Revenue Minister Kelly O'Dwyer point to $4 billion in assessments raised on multinationals in the past year alone - including $1bn from 10 tech companies - as evidence the crackdown is working.

They are also very happy with one of Joe Hockey's last achievements as treasurer, the Multinational Anti Avoidance Law, saying it has encouraged tech groups and other multinationals to bring their operations onshore.

"We have completely and utterly backed the ATO to the hilt," O'Dwyer told The Weekend Australian. This included ignoring the complaints of companies stung in the crackdown.

"People don't get to choose whether or not they pay tax - you've got to pay the right amount of tax," she said.

Konza said Australians "should be confident that the companies we've been working on, the ones that we've finished, are now paying the right amount of tax under the law".

He was keen to dispel "scepticism we'd collect that money".

"Of that $1bn, we've already collected $800 million in cash, so I just want to reassure you that the results are real and the collection is real too." Even the Labor opposition doesn't quibble with the result. Instead, it plays down the effect of the MAAL and claims credit for the haul by pointing out it was largely achieved under legislation passed while it was in government, over opposition from the Coalition.

Having taken on big tech and the powerful oil and gas industry, the ATO now has the global pharmaceutical industry in its sights - better known as big pharma. The Weekend Australian can reveal it has 12 audits of pharma companies under way, with another eight groups engaged in voluntary discussions with the ATO over their pricing arrangements.

"It's really about whether the right share of profit has been landed in Australia for the functionality carried out here," Konza said.

He said the ATO was also still keeping a close eye on sales hubs in tax havens used by resources companies including BHP Billiton and Rio Tinto, and has concerns about intellectual property being shifted offshore.

It was in February last year that Jordan used an appearance before Senate estimates to publicly lose his patience with big multinationals. In an extraordinary outburst, he accused multinational corporations of "stooging" the ATO by playing games and stringing it along, dragging out assessments for as long as possible.

"Enough is enough - no more of this," Jordan told the Senate. But, according to Konza, Jordan had been focused on the problem for much longer - since shortly after he succeeded Michael D'Ascenzo as head of the ATO in 2013.

"What had happened was that the Commissioner had asked us to get on to the issue, and then after three years he said 'enough is enough' because he felt that progress had not been fast enough," Konza said.

"The tax office tries to be fair in all its dealings, and it has processes that try to always give people a fair go and an even break, but sometimes in the hands of the professional adviser who understands our processes and our policies very well, you can get gaming of those policies.

"When you have taxpayers who are trying to stooge us, who are trying to game the system, you need to react firmly." Konza said some multinationals went to extraordinary lengths to evade the ATO's attempts to get a grip on what they were actually doing here in Australia.

"We would require information and it would take us months to get an agreement as to the sort of information that we could get, and then we'd send out a request for information and it would literally take nine months to get information back, but it would be incomplete," he said.

"We would have people that we wanted to interview and there'd be a delay getting access to that, and by the time we get in contact with them we'd discover they'd been transferred overseas in the meantime." Konza and fellow deputy commissioner Jeremy Hirschhorn, who is responsible for the taxation of public groups, looked through the ATO casebook for taxpayers who were "drifting" and came up with seven targets.

"Originally we thought we'd get those seven cases finished and we would raise $2bn," Konza said.

"In the end, strictly speaking as at 30 June only six of those cases had been finished - the seventh has been settled since - but six of those cases have been finished for $3.1bn. So not only did we get the cases finished but as it turned out the actual liabilities were much higher than we'd expected." Clayton Utz tax partner Niv Tadmore said the ATO's message "has been taken very seriously by multinationals".

"I think the seriousness the ATO put into these procedures has been felt," he said. However, he didn't think the ATO could keep up the pressure indefinitely. "I think the balance will shift over time - at the moment it's been very intensive," he said.

Jason Ward, who runs the Australian arm of global activist group Tax Justice Network, said the ATO " should be congratulated on their efforts, they have made significant progress".

"However, the notion that the job is done and now multinationals will all pay their fair share is a complete farce," he said.

Ward rattled off a list of further reforms - including changes to the petroleum resources rent tax, a crackdown on stapled securities and a beneficial ownership register - he claims are needed to "make sure corporations pay what they should to support our schools, hospitals and other public services".

Also calling for stricter laws is Queensland Labor senator Chris Ketter, who pointed to evidence Facebook this week gave to the Senate Economics References Committee he chairs.

The tech giant continues to book Australian income in Ireland using a loophole in MAAL that enables the practice as long as the transaction doesn't touch Australia. "Tuesday's hearing showed that multinational companies are still restructuring their businesses to avoid paying tax in Australia," Ketter said.

Konza points out the ATO couldn't lay claim to some transactions due to international tax law.

"What you do see is that the smaller clients in Australia, they'll go on to the website overseas and place their ads in an automated fashion," he said. "In those instances we don't have a taxing right and that's been the case for almost 100 years."However, O'Dwyer was quick to point out Facebook was still under audit - and that other tech companies hit by audits had restructured to bring all their businesses onshore. "It would surprise me if there are others under audit who weren't similarly affected," she said.

urn:contentItem:5XPB-N231-JBJ7-N0G0-00000-00Big questions for Big Tech in 20202019-12-09T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:21:19ZLexisNexisBig questions for Big Tech in 2020John Davidson

Some Big Tech companies have not mended their ways, despite the threat of heavy regulation and demergers if they continue on their present destructive path.

A gentle summer's breeze rustling through the tree tops isn't the type of weather event we typically give a name to.

There's no Gust Gustav, no Zephyr Zoe bearing down on you as you read this. But cyclones and hurricanes, these we name. If it has energy enough to be an existential threat, we christen it.

So the fact there's a name for the trouble Big Tech has gotten itself into - albeit a portmanteau taken from "tech" and "backlash" - suggests this trouble might do more than upset a few hairdos.

One can only hope the techlash upsets the balance of power, which for too long has been held by an elite few Silicon Valley and Seattle billionaires, too many of whom have abused that power to enrich themselves at untold political, social and human cost.

But the techlash is now entering its third year, and its impact has not been what one might have hoped for. It's been a headwind for Big Tech, to be sure, but not the hurricane required.

While some Big Tech companies have backed away from some of their more destructive practices - Twitter has now banned political advertising on its platform, slowing social media's river of disinformation ever so slightly - others have not mended their ways, despite the threat of heavy regulation and demergers if they continue on their present path.

As recently as last week, Unicef was still begging Facebook to stop publishing "incredibly irresponsible" anti-vaccination propaganda, years after the social media platform was first identified as a contributor to the re-emergence of life-threatening but preventable diseases.

(But, of course, the billionaire founder of Facebook, Mark Zuckerberg, has defended Facebook's publication of tracts denying the Holocaust, and its acceptance of paid political advertisements it knows to contain lies, arguing it's important for the public to hear falsehoods. It may be naive of Unicef to think that Facebook would eliminate anti-vaxxer content from its platform, just because children are dying.)

China v America

So what would have to happen in 2020, to finally make the techlash a storm worth having?

The storm brewing in the Pacific - the decoupling of the US and Chinese tech sectors - which looks likely to gather strength next year, will almost certainly shift the balance of power away from the US West Coast. But whether this will diminish the power of Big Tech, or simply embolden it, remains to be seen.

Having been banned from using American suppliers for its phones, China's telecommunications giant Huawei this September came out with a smartphone, the Mate 30, which contained no US-made hardware whatsoever, and ran a version of the Android operating system that lacked any services provided by Big Tech company Google.

More recently, the Chinese government is reported to have embarked on a "3-5-2 policy" to remove US-made technology from all government offices and public institutions, at a rate of 30 per cent removal in 2020, 50 per cent in 2021, and the remaining 20 per cent in 2022.

China, in short, is being forced to create a stand-alone tech sector, drastically increasing the likelihood big American tech companies such as Facebook and Google will face competitive threats on a scale they've never dealt with before.

The question is, will the decoupling lead to a Balkanisation of tech, under which Facebook might see off a competitor such as Beijing's TikTok, it having been banned from the US and its allies by executive decree, just as Huawei was banned?

Or will the decoupling loosen Big Tech's grip on society, diminishing the global power of these American platforms to the point where regulators finally feel they can get on top of the problem?

While we wait to see how China changes the technology landscape, there is one thing lawmakers and regulators can do.

In 2020, they can make good on their promise to end the special dispensations tech companies have from the rules that govern all other companies.

If, for instance, traditional transport companies must pay their workers minimum wage, then technology-based transport companies should, too.

If, for instance, traditional publishers and broadcasters are to face punishment when they publish defamation or falsehoods or incite violence or hatred, then technology-based publishers and broadcasters should, too.

And if these winds of change prove so strong that some technology companies risk collapse, then that's a problem for Big Tech to solve, not lawmakers.

If finally imposing social and legal norms on the likes of Uber and Facebook would undermine their business, then one could only conclude those businesses were never built on solid foundations in the first place.

urn:contentItem:4KX2-7DM0-TXJ2-N27S-00000-00Big questions will be on IT's agenda in '042003-12-18T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:21:19ZLexisNexisREPORT ON BUSINESS: TECHNOLOGYe-insiderPg. B13Big questions will be on IT's agenda in '04DAVID TICOLL

Two thousand and four should be the year that information technology management peeks from the dunce corner it landed in after Y2K, the dot-com crash and generalized economic malaise. Life won't be much easier, but at least IT will once again bite into interesting issues - ones that can make real differences for firms. This is oodles better than continually dealing with chief financial officers whose selective hearing limits chats to the topic of IT budget cuts.

My IT management issues agenda for 2004 includes three topics in each of three areas: technologies, applications and management. It may not be definitive, but it ought to convince you that the next year won't be boring.

In technologies, the hot toys of 2004 will be little things that talk. Radio-frequency ID tags will be on offer for financial services, supply chains, livestock - you name it. Voice over the Internet will become an increasingly viable and cheap alternative to the phone company's version of long distance. And we'll begin to hear about commercial mesh networks: cellphones that liberate you from companies such as Bell Mobility.

A second technology decision will be the open-source option. Linux is at the centre of an increasingly coherent constellation that, in 2004, will openly challenge Microsoft where you work: On the desktop. You won't dump your existing Windows and Office platforms, but people will be asking "why not try out Linux for new users?" in offshore locations of call centres, for example. Some big company may well announce a plan for a wholesale conversion to the Linux constellation.

A third big tech decision for you in 2004 is your stand on telecom deregulation. Bell Canada chief executive officer Michael Sabia has opted for: If anyone can emerge from the game victorious, it's he who carries the ball today. Your company may well agree. Or not. What are your economic and business interests as telecom succumbs to a technology revolution? And how will you make those interests known?

Moving into the applications area, the latest flavour is hot and cold running applications, thanks to software and technology infrastructure on demand. This is a tweak on outsourcing whereby vendors provide application tools and processing capacity as needed. When you buy computer hardware and software licences up front, you may spend more than necessary because you must anticipate peak demands. In an on-demand model, vendors theoretically pass on their savings from risk portfolio economies of scale, since they support many customers at once. The smart decision is not whether to go with on-demand; instead it's where, when and how to do it.

A new area of applications investment to consider for 2004, if it hasn't hit you already, is "reporting." For firms that report in the United States, a key driver is the Sarbanes-Oxley Act. Canada's balkanized market regulators are still playing catch-up in this area, while some business lobbies continue to argue that we don't need more reporting anyway. The fact is, though, more transparent reporting improves business performance, market credibility and shareholder value. Next-generation applications (such as portals for board members and various stakeholders) and enabling technologies (such as XBRL) will reduce costs, vouchsafe accuracy, and improve access for interested parties.

Transparent reporting raises a business dilemma: privacy and security. How do you protect competitive secrets in a transparent world? What about the privacy of employee and client data? Just today an executive described how his firm struggles with the fact that it provides conservative and safe guidance to financial markets, and tells employees that the real plan is significantly higher. Some might say the answer is to put the kibosh on market guidance altogether. But the deeper issue remains.

The third major area is about broader issues of IT management. My No. 1 topic here harks back to the dunce corner. Many IT executives are indeed in the doldrums. The lucky ones have been booted off the executive committee and had their budgets slashed. The unlucky ones have simply been fired. Now is the time to go on the offensive. IT must continue to reduce its own costs while proving its ability to improve productivity across the business. But as the economy warms up, productivity will mean more than reducing labour hours. It will also mean helping the business get better at innovation and at enticing and keeping customers.

Outsourcing is a management dilemma that looms more than ever. Last week Lou Dobbs announced on CNN for five nights a rogue's gallery of big-name corporations involved in offshore contracting. As the Canadian dollar rises and competition intensifies, outsourcing - including offshore contracting - rears its head right here. How to balance the cost-risk equations of moving IT work around the world? Will so-called near-shore work that Canadians do for U.S. firms offset the impact of offshore contracting of Canadian jobs? Anyway, what's fairer - keeping jobs in rich Canada or creating jobs in emerging economies? Whatever you believe, our labour markets will likely be roiled.

All this ties into the third key management issue: The unfortunate education and experience bias of today's IT professionals. Few of today's universities require computer science students to take courses in the arts or humanities. In fact few even require basic business skills. It's no wonder business people continually express frustration with their IT counterparts. Make 2004 your year to broaden horizons. It will be a good investment, and fun to boot.

(Corrections to last week's column. Bad news: Factiva article retrievals on Microsoft Office 2003 aren't free after all. Good news: Enfish, the Google for your PC, works on Windows XP.) Happy holidays!

David Ticoll's new book is The Naked Corporation: How the Age of Transparency Will Revolutionize Business, written with Don Tapscott.
